E0C8F6CDF88C48059F5671385A75BD7B.description: Investigate the work being done in preparation for future spacetravel and make predictions about future achievements related to living and working in space.

33E73780EB364182AEAD139428D4D499.description: Design a model of a habitable space vehicle that can travel to and return from a student-selected location in the inner solarsystem.

5C866D28FBAD4DE495695703FCCD1EC4.description: Identify potential personal, societal, technological, and environmental barriers to living and working in space.

BB79C133645844C389CC443E97E95AF4.description: Describe instances where scientific ideas and discoveries have led to new inventions and applications (e.g., lunar buggy, spaceshuttle, Canadarm, Dextre, and the International Space Station) that support human exploration of space and which have extended scientific knowledge related to living and working in space.

A010817C9B354D249280A28F4DA395FC.description: Research the various work roles and worldwide locations requiredto support human spaceflight programs.

B7151138850444B8BCD1267BF56A83CD.description: Investigate how astronauts are able to meet their basic needs (e.g., food, water, shelter, and waste elimination) while living andworking in space

1E29C869CD0C425E80BB7C91175B411B.description: Construct a timeline of Canadian and worldwide space exploration programs related to living and working in space, including collaborative efforts among countries.

A6CEB5720F914FDBBB94A56CF73A182C.description: Evaluate past, current, and possible future contributions of space exploration programs including space probes and human spaceflight, which support living and working in the inner solar system.

BFDE717606464D0298785F74E751EEFB.description: Propose questions related to astronomical phenomena to investigate using models and simulations, such as “Do other planets exhibit phases?”, “How would seasons on Earth differ if Earth were not tilted?”, “How would patterns of eclipses change if the sun, Earth, or moon were different diameters or positioned at different locations?”.

8CC4547C3F0B40CA9EB7344EC3DEA2C5.description: Model the relative positions of the sun, Earth, and moon todemonstrate moon phases and lunar and solar eclipses.

36D186F9B01B453C962557B38ACDBAFB.description: Consider alternate models of seasons and explanations for those models (e.g., the six-season model of the Woodland Cree, the rainy and dry seasons of some tropical and subtropical regions).

20D1FF69B0D64E01B547C0006A8193C5.description: Propose explanations for how the yearly cycle of seasons might differif Earth’s axis were not tilted.

70EFF5461B22499CA21FE676684660E5.description: Demonstrate how Earth’s rotation causes the day and night cycle and how Earth’s 23.5° tilt and revolution around the sun causes the yearly cycle of seasons.

8B140E99F47C4C8D95E066128DDB205F.description: Propose personal explanations for the causes of seasons, phases, and eclipses.

582F80BDEAA94A208E0E8A1AA2F9AFBA.description: Demonstrate the importance of selecting appropriate processes for investigating scientific questions and solving technological problems by explaining why astronomy is considered a part of science but astrology is not.

7E84A147D96446A6B6C29DE14070521B.description: Examine ways in which humans have represented understanding of or interest in astronomical phenomena through music, dance,drama, visual art, or stories.

E7225BAF11DC4131953A065965B5A828.description: Examine how people of different cultures, including First Nations, have recorded (e.g., medicine wheel, Mayan calendar, Stonehenge, pyramids) and used understandings of astronomical phenomena (e.g., positions of the stars and/or planets) to solve practical problems such as the appropriate time to plant and harvest crops, to support navigation on land and water, or to foretell significant events through stories and legends.

1597FFD6B6604C21846429DE8EC4B347.description: Assess the efficacy of various methods ofrepresenting and interpreting astronomical phenomena, including phases, eclipses, and seasons.

9D74CE396AEE441184A850C232884D9B.description: Explain how evidence is continually questioned in order to validate scientific knowledge about the solar system.

08B93423D4A2403FB2AE5D6324228C5A.description: Evaluate the usefulness and accuracy of scale-distance and scale-size models of the major components of the solar system.

21005325A6704226BF32B02D555E2B04.description: Create scale-distance and/or scale-size models to represent the major components of the solar system.

8E76739CD1B142E7B1CAAF9A4248C5E5.description: Describe objects in the heavens, as indicated through First Nations and Métis art and stories or by Elders or traditional knowledge keepers.

E0C53DB3CED84534A73388AFA80DE68E.description: Use star charts and astronomy guides to investigate the night sky, including constellations, and record observations using notes in point form, data tables, simple diagrams, and/or charts.

D751D23FD49146F59037C2FC1726E9BE.description: Evaluate the validity and usefulness of different sources ofinformation about the physical characteristics of the solar system.

36DA3669467C4D1D94AF9AF4DE24EF3A.description: Construct a timeline of Canadian and worldwide research efforts related to understanding the major components of the solarsystem.

7A31BEC0A17C4183828F27DA95FB12B2.description: Analyze historical and current technological developments thathave enabled human observation of the major components of the solar system.

BEC2C4B0BC4D4D3584EA692FD897180D.description: Use a variety of sources and technologies to gather and compile pertinent information about the physical characteristics of the major components of the solar system.

C83FDD8015D24C89AE68BDFCF94377F3.description: Research and represent the physical characteristics of the major components of the solar system, including the sun, planets, moons, asteroids, and comets.

CFD8590C94DF497491072B8D82977A35.description: Earth and Space Science: Our Solar System (SS)

62E8D4267C3E463589A34C6C7B970968.description: Propose designs for futuristic flying devices that meet a particular student-identified need.

CEE48C904ACB400FBB6BB8D03E1ADE0A.description: Propose designs for futuristic flying devices that meet a particular student-identified need.

20099B67214E4DD5A31281F6B6FE5458.description: Identify new questions or problems about flight that arise through the prototype design process.

4345498EB3054A3BA85EB3DBD3DB3806.description: Analyze personally collected data and suggest improvements to a prototype design. Communicate procedures and results ofprototype design, construction, testing, and evaluation in a technical design report.

157DEDBEA0314BF68D7E7EB604450389.description: Demonstrate and explain the importance of selecting appropriate processes for investigating scientific questions and solving technological problems (e.g., explain why it isimportant to change one variable while keeping others constant in designing and testing prototypes of flying objects).

09DBE5134BD64322A25E0DF3DF44794D.description: Work collaboratively to collect relevant observations and data to evaluate the performance of a prototype of an object that will fly.

89044731A2BF4E399F1A755A231F7FD4.description: Select and carefully use appropriate tools in manipulating materials and in building prototypes.

4124B7FC14A1463097FCF7EE7E987B4C.description: Work collaboratively with classmates to define criteria for judging the performance and aesthetics of a prototype of a flying object.

33D10AA8B4744DCAAFECB880C362A390.description: Construct a prototype of a flying object that meetsstudentspecified performance and aesthetic criteria.

9E0CBD6EE12B462F89A1EE90B82A1733.description: Assess the characteristics of flying objects (e.g., balloon, kite, glider, airplane, helicopter, and rocket).

5F049BE273974AB98F976132F16B1FD1.description: Design a working prototype of a flying object that meets specified performance criteria.

CCBFE5B376D2459888E02475F2E3AF13.description: Compare the sources of thrust of various constructed flying devices including the propeller, jet engine, and solid orliquidfuelled rocket.

3F71D2C9EAF84BAD946C0D355BFF718E.description: Provide examples of how science and technology havebeen used to solve problems related to drag in devices thatfly.

AEC4CADA777747E1BC9E5D7056EB3CEB.description: Describe and represent methods for altering drag in flying devices, such as a bird spreading wings or an airplane employing flaps

4941BD35E7864FECB373D5B3FCAECB01.description: Determine how lift is affected by the shape of a surface by planning and carrying out steps to investigate the effect of wing shape on lift.

2D0890B126B342228A6A0554DF7574F2.description: Describe the role of lift in overcoming gravity and enabling devices or living things to fly.

C46E764D644948208E88660FD80B8477.description: Generate questions related to the principles of flight and rephrase those questions in a testable form (e.g., rephrase a question such as “Why can some gliders travel farther than others?”to“What effect does wing shape have on the distance a glider can travel?”).

C90D5C7BEFE84A41B0DF17705C024757.description: Use scientific terminology appropriately (e.g., thrust, drag, lift, and gravity) when communicating ideas about the principles of flight.

43D57825276A46A3880407E14C7A0E4E.description: Diagram how the forces of thrust, drag, lift, and gravity acton living things or devices that fly through the air.

185219D181A84A358C80B1991C0195F2.description: Investigate how the forces of thrust, drag, lift,and gravity act on living things and constructed devices that fly through the air.

3CB0AC0FFF194B969EC09193197EF8F3.description: Describe career opportunities in Canada related to the science and technology of flight.

B5A93D5760234B44A19E418EC8BCDBE4.description: Explain how inventions based on principles of flight have changed the way people work, live, and interact with the environment locally, nationally, and globally (e.g., bush planesin northern Saskatchewan, scheduled airline travel, supply of cargo to remote communities and mine sites, and transoceanic air travel)

1150AE7262334454A95F7D4510DD46A5.description: Describe examples of traditional and modern technologies developed by First Nations, Métis, and other cultures that are based on principles of flight (e.g., atlatl, bow and arrow,slingshot, catapult, boomerang, and trebuchet).

1961C18223BC46BAA204CB3D19C1D2E2.description: Discuss historical and current contributions of individuals, including Canadians, who have contributed to scientific understanding and technological developments related toflight.

5705A0C29DA745F2A115225A736B4EC8.description: Research technological problems that had to be overcome to develop devices that fly (e.g., balloons, kites, gliders, airplanes, helicopters, and rockets) and explain how various creative solutions to those problems have resulted in the developmentof flying devices with different designs.

AF69FF65F9784CB1AFF20549AD54BC80.description: Examine the role of inspiration and aesthetic design in the development of flying devices (e.g., initial attempts at trying to fly were based on observations of birds).

EFC50C72FE07433EA67D2F2E3464E3A7.description: Show how First Nations and Métis art and storytelling highlight understanding of and respect for birds

06CAF27743854CBFB1B768748BAF9043.description: Observe and describe physical characteristics and adaptations that enable birds (e.g., ravens, hawks, loons, geese, hummingbirds, sandpipers, cranes, and sparrows), insects (e.g., mosquitoes, dragonflies, grasshoppers, bees, wasps, and butterflies), and bats to fly.

ABAC09C0E59A4F25B768985F26530F26.description: Examine connections between human fascination with flight and technologies and careers based on the scientific principles offlight

DFA54471BA264D04B5F20375A3D6293A.description: Design, construct, and troubleshoot an electrical circuit that meets one or more student-specified criteria.

E5761492172A4F83AB53A1E0A7A27FD6.description: Construct simple circuits to demonstrate how electrical energy can be controlled to produce light, heat, sound, motion, and magneticeffects

69FBD6738CEC4B0189EDA17D22B82794.description: Draw electrical circuit diagrams to represent simple series andparallel circuits using appropriate symbols(e.g., battery, conductor, light bulb, motor, and switch).

CFDD35EA560A4562AA7CD67C85F71A13.description: Construct and test various combinations of simple electric circuits to determine similarities and differences between series and parallel circuits.

32CC03B3A44E4447B11A09753151DF3E.description: Propose questions to investigate, and practical problems to solve, related to simple series and parallel circuits (e.g.,“What happens when a light bulb is removed from a series or parallel circuit?”, “How can I create a simple circuit using only a battery, light bulb, and one wire?”, “How are light circuits in a house wired?”).

90DBB0023D4647309C4F6FF50FC8BBEE.description: Contrast a closed circuit, open circuit, and short circuit.

B90D0B831E8642B081E774F843B6EF52.description: Compare a variety of electrical pathways by constructing simple circuits.

6128AF134F9244E9BFEE3CA409E371B3.description: State the required characteristics of a simple electric circuit (e.g., a source of electrical energy, a closed path to conduct electricalenergy, and a load to convert the electrical energy into another form of energy).

BA6E9A95791B4725BFE3AB5A5FE3A7C2.description: Explain and model the properties of simple series and parallel circuits.

A309E3058D2B40B3A2619D6F6BD5A7B1.description: Describe the operation of common technologies based on properties of static electricity, current electricity, or electromagnetism.

9B3DB29B70064BA7A29C9F7C0E130AFB.description: Use evidence gathered through research and observation to answer questions related to the physical properties of conductors,insulators, simple circuits, and electromagnets.

24292D9D147D44F58DE2F5D77FC94EFA.description: Plan a set of steps to carry out a fair test of a science-related idea related to electromagnets, such as how to increase the strength ofan electromagnet.

887C86854C9C40199C469AF4B0EE6730.description: Describe the operation of an electromagnet and contrast magnets and electromagnets.

03A7BFA7A9FA44E8B3930035CBBC3E49.description: Explain the role of switches in electrical circuits.

312F52CC34D648F481031ABB5E0D81DB.description: Test the conductivity of a variety of solids and liquids, following a given set of procedures, to identify which materials areconductors and which are insulators, and draw conclusions about the types of materials that work best as conductors and which work best as insulators.

A17FDF4594A9457DA0D08CE20C21CE68.description: Identify appropriate tools, instruments, and materials (e.g., bulbs, batteries, and wires) to use when investigating the properties of conductors, insulators, simple circuits, and electromagnets anduse those tools and apparatus in a manner that ensures personalsafety and the safety of others.

735F5385525A4B11874F9753D2AC3D1B.description: Make predictions, based on observed patterns of events, related to the physical properties of conductors, insulators, simple circuits, and electromagnets and conduct investigations to test thosepredictions.

E4AC2080EE634D70A247067BCB37DCE9.description: Pose questions related to the physical properties of conductors, insulators, simple circuits, and electromagnets (e.g., “How can we determine if an unknown material is a conductor or an insulator?”, “How does a switch work in a simple electric circuit?”, “Whatmaterials work best to create an electromagnet?”).

0D281363143348A9B506A8A41B233E26.description: Identify natural and man-made applications of static electric charge and discharge (e.g., lightning, photocopiers, laser printers, airfilters, and electrostatic paint sprayers).

4F6A71A56E994EE5B9DFBF7080BC261F.description: Describe how results of similar and repeated investigations into the characteristics of static electric charges (e.g., the rubbing together of different substances) may vary and suggest possible explanationsfor identified variations.

C8CD2ACE0C3D45C9B44211278CC92045.description: Conduct investigations to determine the attraction and repulsion of electrostatically charged materials and represent the results ofthose investigations using drawings, sketches, tables, charts, and/or other representations.

F42D900E38D249318497F7ED4712EE5C.description: Investigate the characteristics and applications of static electric charges, conductors, insulators, switches, and electromagnetism.

8376DB147C8F43C4BF17CFAA78E3CBA9.description: Research employers and careers related to electrical energy generation, distribution, and conservation in Saskatchewan.

EA01D073CAD24DADA2A6035C58E48C91.description: Explain potential dangers of electricity at home, school, and the workplace and suggest ways individuals can minimize those dangers.

339792867F53403587269685769259E3.description: Identify factors that affect electrical energy consumption at home, school, and in the workplace and propose methods of decreasing electrical energy consumption that can help to conserve natural resources and protect the environment.

4B0CE1D241A145ADBC1F0C37B57AEBE5.description: Locate and categorize by type the large-scale electrical energy generation facilities in Saskatchewan and explain how electrical energy is transmitted from those facilities to locations throughoutthe province.

879B8347A3F943938A431A84E2446DA2.description: Describe how electrical energy is generated from hydroelectric, coal, natural gas, nuclear, geothermal, biomass, solar, and wind sources and categorize these resources as renewable or non-renewable.

7F92C982C3C94077BD68A7B2C98E5178.description: Provide examples of the types of energy sources used to provide heat and light to homes in the past and describe ways in which electricity-based technologies have changed the way people work, live, and interact with the environment in Saskatchewan.

F6A22FAA8ADD44E38CAFF80111365046.description: Assess personal, societal, economic, and environmental impacts of electricity use in Saskatchewan andpropose actions to reduce those

58E4E64098FB40F1BD632CB86A61CA26.description: Discuss positive and negative impacts of micro-organismsfor humans (e.g., food production and spoilage, fermentation, pasteurization, water and sewage treatment, human digestion, composting, disease spread and prevention, and biological warfare).

AC95210EFD86499F8ECF658A89E42087.description: Critique representations or depictions of micro-organisms in a variety of texts (e.g., science fiction, cartoons, movies, music, and poetry).

F19AD8C650B44419BE34C017795F523F.description: Compare cultural (including First Nations and Métis), historical, and scientific understandings and explanations of disease, including the contributions of scientists such asJohn Snow and Louis Pasteur to the germ theory.

AEC6B396889447ABB3610D003C859E5A.description: Design and conduct an investigation of the factors that influence how quickly micro-organisms break down organic matter (e.g., build a composter in a 2L plastic bottle and vary conditions such as the amount of water, soil, light, and combinations of waste products)

CB75CEEEE8E349F0876A0AAB25243B87.description: Explain how micro-organisms meet their basic needs, including moving around and obtaining food, water, and oxygen.

0C49C903DEBE4673BB4F785BA80D4421.description: Observe and represent, using words and diagrams, characteristics of micro-organisms obtained from studentor teacher-collected water samples (e.g., bottled water,tap water, rain barrel, pond, creek, slough, and river water).

073B104EF57648C28E345C6DA35D4398.description: Choose and correctly use appropriate tools (e.g., magnifying glasses, optical microscopes, and video microscopes) to study living organisms that cannot be seen with the naked eye.

6CE07AF1353F4D5190DB98F55BEF8211.description: Assess effects of micro-organisms on past and present society, and contributions of science and technology to human understanding of microorganisms.

81B56569E4B04DB9B222CB115DED48E2.description: Suggest reasons to explain how results of similar and repeated studies of the adaptations of organisms may vary and suggest possible explanations for variations(e.g., independent studies may reveal different responses by polar bears to temperature changes or pollution).

07D437EA9C3D48E1AFDBB488970E3DC0.description: Research the advantages of particular structures or behaviours of organisms that suit different environments (e.g., how different bird beaks are best suited to obtain different types of food, how different types of footstructure are best suited for different environments).

D96BC74E1971493BB6F68D6895E27519.description: Compare closely-related animals that live in different parts of the world and propose explanations for any differencesin their structures and behaviours.

F12FD0BAFE2A405CACBDD5BDCA89D998.description: Gather information from a variety of sources (e.g., Elder, traditional knowledge keeper, naturalist, textbook, nonfiction book, museum display, encyclopaedia, and website) to answer student-generated questions about the structural and behavioural adaptations of organisms.

2168E5568F904EA68B22FA4D1F761997.description: Suggest reasons why specific species of organisms have or might become endangered or extinct.

99E6A593971D4A8887158051EF3B544E.description: Explain how scientists use fossils and the fossil record as a source of information to identify changes or diversity in species over long periods of time.

1B8631CFAE934CBCB300CAFCEFFEE587.description: Describe examples of adaptations to structures and behaviours (e.g., flippers, webbed feet, night-time vision, wide wings, camouflage colouring, migration, and hibernation) that have enabled living things to adapt to their environments in the long term

426D1A98743C4608A900D6DE41B03DA3.description: Describe examples of structures and behaviours, including seasonal changes, which help living things survive in their environments during the lifetime of the organism.

48CBEABB675A4CC49B1D3CF710C60DE6.description: Show interest and curiosity in learning about organisms’ adaptations to different environments by journaling, participating in a nature walk, or sharing science-related information about adaptations (gathered from print or video resources or personal experience) with classmates.

C29A0932ED7542CB94F1862E8BDDB33F.description: Propose questions to investigate related to the structuresand behaviours that help organisms survive in their environments (e.g.,“What advantage are different beaks for birds?”,“Why do owls turn their heads to look sideways?”, “Why do rabbits change colour at different times of the year?”, “Why do caribou migrate?”, “Why do ground squirrels hibernate?”).

37484DCA16BC4354AD94425046559766.description: Examine and describe structures and behaviours that help: individual living organisms survive in their environments in the short term and species of living organisms adapt to their environments in the long term.

B11711A34B6548A19F4C648A6BC79D3F.description: Suggest reasons why current biological classification systems for living things are based on structural (internal) characteristics rather than solely on physical appearance or behaviour.

E5C4134160AA41EDB037B942A7A9505D.description: Propose questions for inquiry that arise from personal investigations of characteristics and behaviours of animals.

01E554F19D164BA187102316495BA82D.description: Compare and represent characteristics and behaviours (e.g., body shape, body description, method of respiration, method of reproduction, method of movement, and method of feeding) of student-selected examples of invertebrates (e.g., arthropods, annelids, cnidarids, echinoderms, molluscs, and nematodes)

1989556942354A7486091DE98D4FB448.description: Compare and represent characteristics and behaviours (e.g., body shape, body description, method of respiration, method of reproduction, method of movement, and method of feeding) of student-selected examples of vertebrates.

D0F5085C4F7C4A8683E57E7BE6B7734C.description: Identify characteristics of vertebrates and invertebrates and classify animals as vertebrates or invertebratesfrom drawings, videos, pictures, lists, and/or personal observations.

7721EF22552A42F3A77D13D3F75259F5.description: Analyze the characteristics and behaviours of vertebrates (i.e., mammals, birds,reptiles, amphibians, and fish) and invertebrates.

2C0F21E9AAFC4266BCEE2DCD7C5C5293.description: Critique the use of biological classification systems to aid scientific understanding of living things rather than relying on common, local, or personally chosen names.

E2D23DF4CFAD41CCAB47D534133E2E07.description: Use appropriate scientific terminology to communicate ideas about the diversity of living things (e.g., biotic, abiotic, kingdom, phylum, monera, protist, fungi, plant, animal, vertebrate, and invertebrate).

E2E2ED3B6DF040289986B1F86D3E54A4.description: Illustrate the diversity of living things on Earth by constructing a visual representation (e.g., poster, mobile,slide show, and web page) showing examples from each kingdom of the five kingdom taxonomic model: monera, protists, fungi, plants, and animals.

C436347E081B4B4F88876632DE5F67A0.description: Describe how aspects of First Nations and Métis worldviews (e.g., holistic, interconnectedness, valuing of place-based knowledge) shape their systems of organizing understanding of living things.

7E5B35CF63214AD09FE93FC818730FB9.description: Explore local First Nations and Métis methods of organizing understanding of living things (e.g., two-leggeds, fourleggeds, winged-ones, swimmers, trees, and grasses) and the criteria underlying that understanding (e.g., where animals are found, how animals move, and the uses of plants).

FC2B41E5A2F040CD9A27428267BB8DB7.description: Demonstrate how different classification systems can beused to classify the same set of objects and explain how humans develop and refine classification systems to meet specific needs.

06D0588E4C514FE89FD9F62B7F46CE5D.description: Consider personal observations and ideas as well as those of others (including differing worldviews) when constructing classification systems by asking questions, sharing stories, and responding to classmates’ classificationsystems.

37F79B3EFD7546ED88FCAD219148CA2B.description: Construct and use a classification system to organize living things into groups and subgroups according to studentdeveloped criteria.

B1A75F8E755A425AA13533F96CB49A96.description: Examine how humans organize understanding of the diversity of living things.

BDFA8D45E4874AA7B6C0E99A2784D2AA.description: Identify examples of science and technology-related careers and workplaces which require an understanding of the diversity of living things (e.g., naturalist, zookeeper, palaeontologist, and wildlife biologist).

5A9EC7FC9AB445529C6F16C8968D033C.description: Analyze how First Nations and Métis art and storytelling highlight movement and/or behaviour of living things and reflect a worldview that values all living things.

5027A0CF704848BAA5999992B1B0C321.description: Document the diversity of living things in different terrestrial and aquatic habitats (e.g., grasslands, forests, tundra,deserts, rivers, ponds, and oceans) using print, video, and/or online resources.

21DD07C30F2C4C57B895514A9A1291BA.description: Show respect for other people, living things, and the environment when observing ecosystems.

C711DFE6E48C4729810EFEB33C068256.description: Observe and document the diversity of living things in their local habitat through journaling, a nature walk, sketching, drawing, photographing, video recording, or othermeans.

8DD048DEEB9C41A98C05434B1FA5375F.description: State the characteristics that define all living things(e.g., are made up of one or more cells, require energy forlife processes, respond to stimuli in their environment, and have the ability to reproduce).

2AA35044F81B4F6997F589091B729D2C.description: Recognize, describe, and appreciate the diversity of living things in local and other ecosystems, and explore related careers.

D6BAEB1C6BDE45E19D5A0D5A894562E5.description: Life Science: Diversity of Living Things (DL)
